div.p: Settlement, a sub-element of PLACE available everywhere in Orlando (LIFE and WRITING docs and free-standing events), captures the names of cities, towns, villages, hamlets and areas within larger settlements (for example, districts of London). It encloses just the name of the place, without punctuation. Settlement has optional attributes for Current and Reg. For districts of London or other large cities it is mandatory to use Current attribute for city name and Reg for district name. We need to provide for search results that will deliver *either* London *or* Chelsea, *either* New York *or* Manhattan, and using both attributes is so far the only way to achieve this.

div.codeblock: <place><settlement REG=”Chelsea” CURRENT=”London”>Chelsea</><Region=”Middlesex”</><Geog REG=”England”></></> <place><settlement CURRENT="St Petersburg” REG=”Leningrad”>Leningrad</><Geog=”Russia”></></>.<place><placename>British Museum</><settlement REG="London"><Region=”Middlesex”</><Geog REG=”England”></></>

div.p: See place for general practice issues. More than one settlement sub-element is not allowed within a single Place element: use attributes to provide two names (<PLACE><SETTLEMENT CURRENT="New York City" REG="East Village">East Village</SETTLEMENT><REGION REG="New York"/><GEOG REG="USA"/></PLACE>). Do NOT use two settlement tags to indicate two different cities. If your sentence reads She travelled across the United States, stopping in New York and Chicago, you must include two separate place elements to capture the two settlements, each with its empty but Reg’d Region tag. She travelled across the United States, stopping in <PLACE><SETTLEMENT CURRENT="New York City" REG="East Village">East Village</SETTLEMENT><REGION REG="New York"/><GEOG REG="USA"/></PLACE>
